articles.title: NASA’s SWOT satellite captures Kamchatka megaquake tsunami in striking detail
articles.summary: When a massive 8.8 magnitude earthquake struck off Russia’s Kamchatka Peninsula, NASA and CNES’s SWOT satellite captured a rare and detailed picture of the tsunami that followed. Recorded just over an hour after the quake, the satellite revealed the wave’s height, shape, and path, offering scientists an unprecedented multidimensional view from space.
articles.content:
Data provided by the water satellite, a joint effort between NASA and the French space agency, is helping to improve tsunami forecast models, benefitting coastal communities.

The SWOT (Surface Water and Ocean Topography) satellite captured the tsunami spawned by an 8.8 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Russia's Kamchatka Peninsula on July 30, 11:25 a.m. local time. The satellite, a joint effort between NASA and the French space agency CNES (Centre National d'Études Spatiales), recorded the tsunami about 70 minutes after the earthquake struck.

Disturbances like an earthquake or underwater landslide trigger a tsunami when the event is large enough to displace the entire column of seawater from the ocean floor to the surface. This results in waves that ripple out from the disturbance much like dropping a pebble into a pond generates a series of waves.

"The power of SWOT's broad, paintbrush-like strokes over the ocean is in providing crucial real-world validation, unlocking new physics, and marking a leap towards more accurate early warnings and safer futures," said Nadya Vinogradova Shiffer, NASA Earth lead and SWOT program scientist at NASA Headquarters in Washington.

Data from SWOT provided a multidimensional look at the leading edge of the tsunami wave triggered by the Kamchatka earthquake. The measurements included a wave height exceeding 1.5 feet (45 centimeters), shown in red in the highlighted track, as well as a look at the shape and direction of travel of the leading edge of the tsunami. The SWOT data, shown in the highlighted swath running from the southwest to the northeast in the visual, is plotted against a forecast model of the tsunami produced by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Center for Tsunami Research. Comparing the observations from SWOT to the model helps forecasters validate their model, ensuring its accuracy.

"A 1.5-foot-tall wave might not seem like much, but tsunamis are waves that extend from the seafloor to the ocean's surface," said Ben Hamlington, an oceanographer at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Southern California. "What might only be a foot or two in the open ocean can become a 30-foot wave in shallower water at the coast."

The tsunami measurements SWOT collected are helping scientists at NOAA's Center for Tsunami Research improve their tsunami forecast model. Based on outputs from that model, NOAA sends out alerts to coastal communities potentially in the path of a tsunami. The model uses a set of earthquake-tsunami scenarios based on past observations as well as real-time observations from sensors in the ocean.

The SWOT data on the height, shape, and direction of the tsunami wave is key to improving these types of forecast models. "The satellite observations help researchers to better reverse engineer the cause of a tsunami, and in this case, they also showed us that NOAA's tsunami forecast was right on the money," said Josh Willis, a JPL oceanographer.

The NOAA Center for Tsunami Research tested their model with SWOT's tsunami data, and the results were exciting, said Vasily Titov, the center's chief scientist in Seattle. "It suggests SWOT data could significantly enhance operational tsunami forecasts -- a capability sought since the 2004 Sumatra event." The tsunami generated by that devastating quake killed thousands of people and caused widespread damage in Indonesia.

More About SWOT

The SWOT satellite was jointly developed by NASA and CNES, with contributions from the Canadian Space Agency (CSA) and the UK Space Agency. NASA JPL, managed for the agency by Caltech in Pasadena, California, leads the U.S. component of the project. For the flight system payload, NASA provided the Ka-band radar interferometer (KaRIn) instrument, a GPS science receiver, a laser retroreflector, a two-beam microwave radiometer, and NASA instrument operations. The Doppler Orbitography and Radioposition Integrated by Satellite system, the dual frequency Poseidon altimeter (developed by Thales Alenia Space), the KaRIn radio-frequency subsystem (together with Thales Alenia Space and with support from the UK Space Agency), the satellite platform, and ground operations were provided by CNES. The KaRIn high-power transmitter assembly was provided by CSA.

articles.personality_title: NASA’s SWOT satellite captures detailed images of Kamchatka tsunami
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – On July 30, a powerful earthquake with a magnitude of 8.8 struck off Russia’s Kamchatka Peninsula. Such earthquakes can cause tsunamis, which are large ocean waves that travel far and can be very dangerous to coastal areas.

**What happened** – About 70 minutes after the earthquake, NASA and the French space agency CNES’s SWOT satellite took detailed measurements of the tsunami wave. The satellite recorded the wave’s height, shape, and path as it moved across the ocean. This was one of the first times a satellite captured such clear and precise data of a tsunami from space.

**Impact** – The data from SWOT helps scientists check and improve computer models that predict tsunamis. These models are important because they help warn people in coastal communities before a tsunami arrives. Even though the wave was about 1.5 feet high in the open ocean, it can grow much taller near the shore, making accurate forecasts crucial for safety.

**What’s next step** – Scientists at the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) will use the new data to improve their tsunami warning systems. The success of SWOT’s measurements means future tsunamis could be monitored better from space, leading to faster and more reliable warnings.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s SWOT satellite provided a rare, detailed look at a Kamchatka tsunami that is helping scientists make better forecasts to protect coastal communities worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le satellite SWOT de la NASA capture en détail le tsunami du séisme de Kamchatka
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le 30 juillet, un puissant séisme de magnitude 8,8 a frappé au large de la péninsule de Kamchatka en Russie. Ces séismes peuvent provoquer des tsunamis, de grandes vagues océaniques qui peuvent être très dangereuses pour les régions côtières.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Environ 70 minutes après le séisme, le satellite SWOT de la NASA et de l’agence spatiale française CNES a pris des mesures précises de la vague de tsunami. Le satellite a enregistré la hauteur, la forme et le trajet de la vague alors qu’elle traversait l’océan. C’est l’une des premières fois qu’un satellite capture des données aussi claires et précises d’un tsunami depuis l’espace.

**Impact** – Les données de SWOT aident les scientifiques à vérifier et améliorer les modèles informatiques qui prédisent les tsunamis. Ces modèles sont importants car ils permettent d’alerter les populations côtières avant l’arrivée d’un tsunami. Même si la vague faisait environ 45 centimètres en pleine mer, elle peut devenir beaucoup plus haute près des côtes, ce qui rend les prévisions précises essentielles pour la sécurité.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques du National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) des États-Unis utiliseront ces nouvelles données pour améliorer leurs systèmes d’alerte au tsunami. Le succès des mesures de SWOT signifie que les futurs tsunamis pourront être mieux surveillés depuis l’espace, ce qui permettra des alertes plus rapides et fiables.

**Phrase clé** – Le satellite SWOT de la NASA a offert un regard rare et détaillé sur un tsunami de Kamchatka, aidant les scientifiques à améliorer les prévisions pour protéger les communautés côtières dans le monde entier.
articles.personality_title_es: El satélite SWOT de la NASA captura imágenes detalladas del tsunami de Kamchatka
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El 30 de julio, un poderoso terremoto de magnitud 8.8 sacudió frente a la península de Kamchatka en Rusia. Estos terremotos pueden provocar tsunamis, que son grandes olas oceánicas que pueden ser muy peligrosas para las zonas costeras.

**Qué pasó** – Unos 70 minutos después del terremoto, el satélite SWOT de la NASA y la agencia espacial francesa CNES tomó medidas detalladas de la ola del tsunami. El satélite registró la altura, forma y camino de la ola mientras se movía por el océano. Esta fue una de las primeras veces que un satélite capturó datos tan claros y precisos de un tsunami desde el espacio.

**Impacto** – Los datos de SWOT ayudan a los científicos a verificar y mejorar los modelos informáticos que predicen tsunamis. Estos modelos son importantes porque ayudan a avisar a las personas en las comunidades costeras antes de que llegue un tsunami. Aunque la ola tenía alrededor de 45 centímetros en mar abierto, puede crecer mucho más cerca de la costa, por lo que las predicciones precisas son clave para la seguridad.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos de la Administración Nacional Oceánica y Atmosférica (NOAA) de Estados Unidos usarán estos nuevos datos para mejorar sus sistemas de alerta de tsunamis. El éxito de las mediciones de SWOT significa que los futuros tsunamis podrían monitorearse mejor desde el espacio, llevando a advertencias más rápidas y confiables.

**Frase clave** – El satélite SWOT de la NASA ofreció una mirada rara y detallada a un tsunami en Kamchatka, ayudando a los científicos a mejorar las predicciones para proteger a las comunidades costeras en todo el mundo.
